awd_titl_txt: Concrete Micromechanics Validated with In-Situ Stress and Strain Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will examine the mechanical response of concrete at micrometer to centimeter length scales to validate theories and computational models used to predict its behavior and failure. Concrete is the world’s most-common building material and extensive research efforts are on-going to improve its resiliency and environmental friendliness. Concrete is composed of particles and inclusions with varying properties and dimensions ranging from nanometers to centimeters that interact during mechanical loading. The results of these interactions are captured by theories and computational models in the field of micromechanics. While micromechanics-based theories accurately predict many mechanical properties of concrete, the assumptions underlying these theories have not been validated at small length scales. Furthermore, determining the resolution needed for accurate computational modeling of concrete is still challenging. This research project will employ new, advanced x-ray measurements to assess the response of concrete from micrometers to centimeters, to test the hypotheses underlying micromechanics theories, and to provide the research community with high-fidelity data for validating models. The results of this research are expected to improve predictions of concrete’s mechanical response and promote understanding of its properties. The research results will also be used to teach advanced concepts in a graduate engineering course and to provide research opportunities to under-represented high school students interested in STEM careers.

This research consists of making in-situ x-ray tomography and diffraction measurements of stress and strain at micron to centimeter length scales during mechanical loading of concrete specimens at laboratory and synchrotron facilities. These measurements will be used to validate and extend micromechanics theories, such as Eshelby’s inclusion and Mori-Tanaka’s theories, and their underlying assumptions across length scales. For instance, the measurements will be used to examine whether average inclusion stresses used as intermediate variables in deriving homogenized material properties are accurate and to what degree individual inclusion stresses deviate from the average. The measurements will also be used to examine the accuracy of mesoscale modeling with varying levels of microstructural refinement, addressing open problems related to the length scales that must be captured in such models. The outcomes of the project will be a fundamental understanding of stress and strain variability across length scales in concrete, guidance for mesoscale modeling, and high-fidelity datasets for calibration and validation of theories and models used throughout the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merits: 

Concrete is the world’s most-common construction material. Emission of green-house gases and material degradation are two critical issues that influence the long-term stability of concrete as a future construction material – concrete production is a major contributor of carbon dioxide emissions, and its weather and aging are of major concern for the longevity of the nation’s infrastructure. Efforts to improve concrete’s resilience and sustainability rely heavily on our ability to predict its stiffness, strength, and degradation. Predictions of stiffness and strength have historically used empirical data from experimental testing and theories that treat the material as a continuum or homogeneous solid. On close examination, however, concrete is a very complex composite material featuring a mortar with multiple chemical components, sand grains, and gravel aggregates. Our project’s goal was to understand how loads are transmitted through these components and to develop new predictive models and theories that treat concrete as a truly heterogeneous material.   

Our project used state-of-the-art X-ray measurements which provided a 3D image of concrete with detail on individual component locations down to the scale of 0.001 mm and detail on the forces (or stresses) and displacements (or strains) experienced in each component. These measurements have rarely before been applied to concrete but provided critical information needed to understand how loads are transmitted through different components and to validate models that can resolve those components. The X-ray measurements we used during this project were taken during mechanical compression experiments performed on small concrete specimens at synchrotron facilities in the United States (Argonne National Laboratory) and France (the European Synchrotron Facility). Our measurements revealed that forces and displacements (i.e., stresses and strains) are distributed very heterogeneously across the components of a concrete specimen, even at length scales below 1 mm. One major outcome of our measurements is that theories used in predicting the stiffness and strength of concrete must be improved to account for the observed heterogeneous distribution of forces and displacements – the theories currently do not predict such a heterogeneous mechanical response. 

Our project also developed and used numerical models for concrete which resolved individual components in the material, breaking from the tradition of treating the material as a homogeneous solid. This advance in the field’s ability to model complex materials was made possible by our abilities to (1) visualize individual component locations and (2) validate model predictions not only in terms of macroscopic response but also in terms of microscopic responses (e.g., the forces and stresses felt by individual grains, and the heterogeneity of these forces and stresses). Major outcomes of our work in model development included new methods to generate models from X-ray measurements, a discussion of the level of detail needed in models to accurately predict macroscopic and microscopic responses, and a better understanding of which of the constituent components of concrete influence its stiffness and strength.

Our work has advanced the field’s understanding of how concrete materials support external loads and provided two innovative tools for making predictions: state-of-the-art X-ray measurements and models that resolve individual components at sub-millimeter scales. These tools have the potential to support studies of existing or new concrete materials being assessed for resilience and sustainability.

Broader Impacts:

Our work advanced measurement capabilities, theories, and numerical models for concrete that support broader efforts to improve the health of the nation’s infrastructure and our ability to predict the properties of new concrete materials being developed with lower carbon dioxide emissions. 

Our project engaged one postdoctoral researcher and assistant research scientist, one master’s student, and two undergraduate students. The postdoctoral researcher transitioned to an assistant research scientist role during the execution of this project and subsequently secured a position at a Department of Energy national laboratory where they will continue to advance modeling and testing capabilities related to the nation’s infrastructure. The master’s student transitioned to an industry role at a major technology company where they are developing and testing materials used in common products. One undergraduate student transitioned to Ph.D. studies at an Ivy League graduate school. The other undergraduate student transitioned to a master’s degree program.


Last Modified: 11/14/2024
Modified by: Ryan Hurley
